I think that impressionism is my strength when it comes to art. From far away, an impressionist painting may be clearly of a building, or of a boat (or in many of Monet's cases, of lilies) - the subject is often tangible - but on closer examination, you'll find a multitude of 'imperfections' that collectively work together.

Sometimes I think, gee this is kinda ironic, since I'm also an engineer, and can be OCD/think way to hard about the smallest details. I don't mean to sound closed minded, but being an engineer often requires an unyielding, and sometimes obsessive attention to detail in order to succeed in the task at hand. Then - and I'm thinking this to myself - shouldn't I prefer hyper-realistic, accurate and precise, photograph-like depictions? But art is maleable by constitution, and impressionism - for me at least - is more than often a maleable version of concrete things. There's a playfulness about painting the way I normally do that requires me to step back, to take a breath and to think about the bigger picture, as cheesy as that sounds, and I find it cathartic.

I also have many, I would say, po-po-po-post modern, and 'non-formal' (I suppose), mixed media pieces. Drop me a line if you'd like to see more :). I sort of lose it when crafting those pieces.

Oh! Definitely contact me if you'd like some freelance work done. I'm open to most mediums and genres, and I'm definitely not one to turn down a challenge.
